introduction.p: Here is a brief overview of basic results and definitions concerning sets and the reals that should be assumed for this course.

ul.li: \mb R is the set of real numbers.
\mb Z is the set of integers.
\omega=\setBuilder{z\in\mb Z}{z\geq 0}=\setList{0,1,2,\dots} is the set of natural numbers, which includes zero.
\mb Q=\setBuilder{\frac{z}{n+1}}{z\in\mb Z,n\in\omega} is the set of rational numbers.

theorem.p: De Morgan's Laws: Let \mc A be a collection of subsets of X.
The Archemedian Property of the real numbers guarantees that for each positive real number x>0, there exists a natural number n\in\omega such that \frac{1}{n}\lt x.
Let S\subseteq \mb R be a set of real numbers with a lower bound. Then there exists a greatest lower bound (a.k.a. infimum) \glb S=\inf S.
Let S\subseteq \mb R be a set of real numbers with a lower bound. Then there exists a least upper bound (a.k.a. supremum) \lub S=\sup S.

definition.p: The cardinality of a finite set is the natural number that is equal to the number of elements it contains. For example, S=\setL{-1,\setL{5,-e},\pi} has cardinality |S|=3.
A set S that has an injection with \omega is said to be countable and have cardinality |S|\leq\aleph_0. If a bijection exists, the set is countably infinite and has cardinality |S|=\alpha_0.
A set S that has no injection with \omega is said to be uncountable and have cardinality |S|>\aleph_0.
A set S that has a bijection with \mb R is said to be continuum-sized and have cardinality |S|=\mathfrak c.

lemma.p: For each a,b\in\mathbb R\cup\setL{-\infty,\infty}, the set (a,b)\cap\mathbb Q is infinite and countable, and the set (a,b)\setminus\mathbb Q is infinite and uncoutnable. In particular, every subinterval (a,b) of \mathbb R contains a rational from \mathbb Q and an irrational from \mathbb R\setminus\mathbb Q.
For any functions f:A\to B,g:B\to C and Z\subseteq C, (g\circ f)^\leftarrow[Z]=f^\leftarrow[g^\leftarrow[Z]].
